image.altText: A woman holds Australian flags at a soccer match.

items.synopsis: Bags of blood for an Adelaide mother in need of urgent heart surgery are being flown to Australia from the United Kingdom as the search for matching donors widens.

title.children: 'Needle in a haystack' blood search for Adelaide mum goes international

image.altText: Australian runner Peter Bol smiles as he talks with Kenyan 800m champion Wyclife Kinyamal after a race.

items.synopsis: Australian 800-metre runner Peter Bol has been cleared of doping by Sport Integrity Australia in what he described as "a dream come true".

title.children: Olympian Peter Bol cleared following investigation into doping result

image.altText: White banner saying "another sold" following house sale

items.synopsis: House prices continue to rise, but there are further signs that a recent rebound may be losing steam as spring selling season approaches and the appeal of life outside the cities fades post-pandemic.

title.children: Premium property markets are no longer booming and it 'could be a sign of broader easing'

image.altText: Warren Tredrea

items.synopsis: Former sports presenter Warren Tredrea has taken the stand on the first day of a Federal Court trial where he is seeking nearly $6 million in compensation claiming he was unfairly dismissed by Channel 9 South Australia over his refusal to be vaccinated against COVID-19.

title.children: 'Every presenter stumbles': Warren Tredrea tells court his on-air performance was not grounds for dismissal

image.altText: A desert kurrajong tree sits against a purple night sky.

title.children: The desert kurrajong looks like a child's drawing of a tree, but in the outback it can be a lifesaver

image.altText: Angus Cloud, dressed in a purple top, clasps his hands together on the red carpet.

items.synopsis: The actor, best known for playing drug dealer Fezco in HBO show Euphoria, has died aged 25.

title.children: Euphoria actor Angus Cloud dies

image.altText: A women's soccer team wearing light blue uniforms runs to the sideline celebrating

items.synopsis: With their greatest-ever Women's World Cup victory, the Matildas have shown they are so much more than just Sam Kerr.

title.children: Without their biggest star, the Matildas' win over Canada showed us who they really are

image.altText: Pat Cummins holds the Ashes urn while standing in a group of his fellow players

items.synopsis: An Ashes series that delivered on every promise ends in a 2-2 draw, but with enough memories, emotions and stories to last a lifetime, writes Dean Bilton.

title.children: An unforgettable Ashes series ends in a draw, but provides enough stories to last a lifetime

image.altText: Paul McCartney performs at Glastonbury Festival in Worthy Farm, Somerset, England, Saturday, June 25, 2022.

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Paul McCartney announces Australian tour, and Elon Musk's X sign comes down — get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Music legend Paul McCartney has announced he will tour Australia in October and November of this year. The 81-year-old will perform in Adelaide, Melbourne, Newcastle, Sydney, Brisbane and the Gold Coast. It's part of his Got Back tour which features songs from The Beatles, Wings and his time as a solo artist.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Paul McCartney announces Australian tour

children.content: Music legend Paul McCartney has announced he will tour Australia in October and November of this year.
The 81-year-old will perform in
Adelaide, Melbourne, Newcastle, Sydney, Brisbane and the Gold Coast
It's part of his Got Back tour which features songs from The Beatles, Wings and his time as a solo artist.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US actor, who portrayed Fezco in the HBO television series Euphoria, has died. He was 25. In a statement, HBO says: "We are incredibly saddened to learn of the passing of Angus Cloud. He was immensely talented and a beloved part of the HBO and Euphoria family. We extend our deepest condolences to his friends and family during this difficult time."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Euphoria actor Angus Cloud has died, aged 25

children.content: The US actor, who portrayed Fezco in the HBO television series Euphoria,
has died
He was 25.
In a statement, HBO says:

"We are incredibly saddened to learn of the passing of Angus Cloud. He was immensely talented and a beloved part of the HBO and Euphoria family. We extend our deepest condolences to his friends and family during this difficult time."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Olympian says he has been officially cleared of doping by Sport Integrity Australia. Mr Bol received a suspension in January after initially testing positive to the banned drug EPO. The track star took to social media this morning to announce his exoneration, describing it as "a dream come true". He says the World Anti Doping Agency has agreed to review its EPO testing process to prevent future false positives. You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Dream come true': Peter Bol says he has been officially cleared of doping

featuredLink.title: Olympian Peter Bol exonerated following investigation into doping result

children.content: The Olympian says he has been officially cleared of doping by Sport Integrity Australia.
Mr Bol received a suspension in January after initially testing positive to the banned drug EPO.
The track star took to social media this morning to announce his exoneration, describing it as "a dream come true".
He says the World Anti Doping Agency has agreed to review its EPO testing process to prevent future false positives.
You can read more on this story here:

image.altText: Philip Lowe giving evidence, resting his head on his hand.

items.synopsis: Inflation might be rapidly falling, but economists will stick to their textbooks to argue another rate rise is needed. It's little wonder why it's earned the reputation of being the dismal science, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: Inflation is falling rapidly — but economists are ignoring the signs because their textbooks tell them to

image.altText: On a shelf of coral, some corals are a stark white colour.

items.synopsis: The Great Barrier Reef is likely to avoid being listed as in danger for at least another year as a United Nations body recommends delaying a decision on its World Heritage status.

title.children: Australia was granted a reprieve on the Great Barrier Reef being labelled 'in danger'. Here's why

image.altText: A composite of three sportswomen in pale blue uniforms celebrating.

items.synopsis: Hayley Raso becomes a household name in 45 minutes of football, as Sam Kerr gets another much-needed spell on the sidelines. These are the five talking points from last night.

title.children: Five quick hits — Raso the star in first-half domination and Kerr gets an unexpected rest

image.altText: two happy young girls take a selfie and smile into a phone sipping red wine.

title.children: Could friendship be the key to keeping people in regional areas? These speech pathologist students think so

image.altText: A sinkhole on a cement walkway.

items.synopsis: A local geologist says the limestone sinkhole was probably last open more than 5,000 years ago until the Mount Gambier volcano erupted and filled it with ash.

title.children: Mount Gambier's 4-metre-wide sinkhole an ancient cave previously filled by volcanic ash

image.altText: A man stands talking on the phone looking out the window.

items.synopsis: Telstra is sending letters to its deceased customers despite their family members pleading for the telco to stop the mail.

title.children: Families plead for Telstra to stop sending letters addressed to their dead loved ones

image.altText: Joseph 'Phillip Laycock and Alexander Naggs died in an MRH90 crash

items.synopsis: Warrant Officer Joseph "Phillip" Laycock and Corporal Alexander Naggs were two of the four men believed to have died when their army MRH90 Taipan helicopter crashed into the water off north Queensland last week.

title.children: Loved ones release statements honouring men who died in Taipan chopper crash

image.altText: The Aboriginal flag and the Australian flag atop the Sydney Harbour Bridge

items.synopsis: Voter disinterest and confusion are threatening to create an uninformed outcome on the Voice referendum, researchers warn.

title.children: Calls for non-Indigenous Australians to research the Voice to avoid turning 'apathy into a vote'

image.altText: Rohan smiles, sitting next to an adult on the couch. He has brown hair.

items.synopsis: Juvenile arthritis is one of the most common chronic diseases affecting Australian children, but a scarcity of specialists is making diagnosis and care a challenge.

title.children: Rohan developed a limp at 18 months — it took months to discover he had juvenile arthritis

image.altText: England captain Ben Stokes hugs bowler Stuart Broad after the fifth Ashes Test at The Oval.

items.synopsis: Australia falls 49 runs short of England in its chase on the last day of the final Test of the Ashes, with a 2-2 draw good enough for Australia to retain the Urn.

title.children: Australia's batting collapses on last day of Ashes as series ends in a draw

image.altText: Man sits in red seat with grey suit

items.synopsis: The actor, best known for the cultural phenomenon Pee-wee Herman, has died aged 70.

image.altText: A tight shot of Jim Chalmers head, he wears a suit and red tie stands in front of a blue curtain

items.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers says Australia's fight against inflation is not yet over as the Reserve Bank weighs a possible interest rate hike at its meeting. Follow live.

title.children: Chalmers says Australia making 'welcome progress' in inflation fight but 'not there yet' as RBA weighs possible rate hike

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Debt collector Credit Corp says annual profit fell over the year. The firm's net profit for 2023 fell 9 per cent to $91.3 million as loans were repaid and as costs rose in the US after it hired more workers. Credit Corp says demand for loans remains strong, although it saw a rise in people having problems repaying their loans. "Consumer lending demand remained strong as credit-impaired customers re-leveraged post COVID." "Delinquency increased part way through the year, but a prompt collection response and tightened credit settings have ensured that arrears and losses remain within pro-forma levels." The lenders says the outlook for the US is uncertain and it expects debt purchase earnings in Australia to further contract in 2024 because of low volumes. Investors get a final dividend payout of 47 cents a share. Its loan book expanded by 43 per cent over the year to $358 million. Credit Corp lends to people with poor credit records and buys distressed loans from other lenders.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Credit Corp shares take a hit after profit fall

children.content: Debt collector Credit Corp says annual profit fell over the year.
The firm's net profit for 2023 fell 9 per cent to $91.3 million as loans were repaid and as costs rose in the US after it hired more workers.
Credit Corp says demand for loans remains strong, although it saw a rise in people having problems repaying their loans.
"Consumer lending demand remained strong as credit-impaired customers re-leveraged post COVID."
"Delinquency increased part way through the year, but a prompt collection response and tightened credit settings have ensured that arrears and losses remain within pro-forma levels."
The lenders says the outlook for the US is uncertain and it expects debt purchase earnings in Australia to further contract in 2024 because of low volumes.
Investors get a final dividend payout of 47 cents a share.
Its loan book expanded by 43 per cent over the year to $358 million.
Credit Corp lends to people with poor credit records and buys distressed loans from other lenders.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The US economy is on track to avoid a hard landing, and by all accounts appears to have delayed a recession — or dodged one entirely. Now markets in the US are expecting no further rate hikes, however chief investment officer of AXA Investment Managers, Chris Iggo, says there could be "a long plateau". "Markets expect no more US rate hikes," Mr Iggo wrote. "The comments made to accompany the decision to raise the Fed Funds Rate to a range of 5.25% to 5.50% did not explicitly say the Federal Reserve’s (Fed) tightening cycle was over, but the insistence on future policy decisions being data-dependent suggest we are at the peak of the policy-rate cycle. "Activity and inflation data would need to reverse their recent softening to get the Fed to conclude that more rate hikes are necessary. "Importantly there was nothing to suggest the Fed sees any need to signal when it would start easing. "It does not expect a recession in 2023 and remains wedded to the idea that the US economy will experience a soft landing. "
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: No further US rate hikes, according to market expectations

children.content: The US economy is on track to avoid a hard landing, and by all accounts appears to have delayed a recession — or dodged one entirely.
Now markets in the US are expecting
no further rate hikes
however chief investment officer of AXA Investment Managers,
Chris Iggo,
says there could be "a long plateau".
"Markets expect no more US rate hikes," Mr Iggo wrote.
"The comments made to accompany the decision to raise the Fed Funds Rate to a range of 5.25% to 5.50% did not explicitly say the Federal Reserve’s (Fed) tightening cycle was over, but
the insistence on future policy decisions being data-dependent suggest we are at the peak of the policy-rate cycle
"Activity and inflation data would need to reverse their recent softening to get the Fed to conclude that more rate hikes are necessary.
"Importantly there was nothing to suggest the Fed sees any need to signal when it would start easing.
"It does not expect a recession in 2023 and remains wedded to the idea that the
US economy will experience a soft landing.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has opened higher this morning as investors await the RBA's decision on interest rates this afternoon. The ASX 200 index is up 0.3 per cent, with most sectors going up. Miners and energy stocks are boosting the market after a rise in commodity prices overnight. Healthcare firms are in the red. Here are the best and worst performers on the ASX 200 in early trade: Gold Road Resources:+6.7 per cent Paladin Energy: +5.8 per cent Lynas Rare Earths: +5.2 per cent Credit Corp Group: -15.2 per cent Abacus Property Group: -14.3 per cent Johns Lyng Group: -1.8 per cent
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher ahead of RBA rate decision

children.content: The Australian share market has opened higher this morning as investors await the RBA's decision on interest rates this afternoon.
The ASX 200 index is up 0.3 per cent, with most sectors going up.
Miners and energy stocks are boosting the market after a rise in commodity prices overnight.
Healthcare firms are in the red.
Here are the best and worst performers on the ASX 200 in early trade:
Gold Road Resources:+6.7 per cent
Paladin Energy: +5.8 per cent
Lynas Rare Earths: +5.2 per cent
Credit Corp Group: -15.2 per cent
Abacus Property Group: -14.3 per cent
Johns Lyng Group: -1.8 per cent
